A: If you're going on a summer vacation, make sure to arrange for someone to look after crops like tomatoes and zucchinis, as they grow strongest in the middle of summer. Without regular care, these crops may suffer. Alternatively, you can plant cool-season crops such as lettuce, kale, peas, and root vegetables during the cooler months of late spring and early fall when you can tend to them.

Q: Why is it worth investing in high-quality seeds? A: Investing in high-quality seeds is worthwhile because they ensure better germination rates and result in higher yields at harvest time. While seed packets are cheaper than buying individual plants, poor-quality seeds that don’t germinate can waste both your time and money. Spending a little more on quality seeds in spring will give you a more productive garden.

Q: What should you consider when planning where to plant each vegetable in your garden? A: When planning where to plant each vegetable in your garden, consider the height of the plants and how much sunlight they will receive. Plant tall vegetables, like pole beans on a trellis or sweet corn, on the north side so they don’t shade shorter plants. If you have shady areas, reserve them for cool-season vegetables, like lettuce and peas, that appreciate shade as the weather warms up. Perennial crops, such as asparagus or rhubarb, should have permanent locations or beds.

Q: When should cool-season and warm-season vegetables be planted? A: Cool-season vegetables, such as lettuce, broccoli, and peas, should be planted in the cooler weather of early spring or fall. Warm-season vegetables, like tomatoes, peppers, and cucumbers, should be planted after the soil has warmed up, typically in late spring or early summer. This timing ensures optimal growing conditions for each type of crop.

Q: How can you use plant height to optimize your garden layout? A: To optimize your garden layout, plant tall vegetables, like pole beans or sweet corn, on the north side of the garden so they don’t cast shadows on shorter plants. This ensures that all plants receive the sunlight they need to thrive. If your garden has areas of unavoidable shade, use them for cool-season vegetables that can tolerate less sunlight as the weather heats up.

Q: What is the difference between annual and perennial crops? A: Annual crops, like tomatoes, lettuce, and cucumbers, need to be planted each year. Perennial crops, such as asparagus, rhubarb, and some herbs, come back every year and should be given permanent locations or beds in your garden, as they will stay in the same spot season after season.

Q: Why is it important to consider the 'days to maturity' of different crops? A: It's important to consider the 'days to maturity' because some crops, like radishes and bush beans, mature quickly and have a short harvest period, while others, like tomatoes, take longer to produce but will continue to yield for an extended period. Knowing this information, which is usually listed on seed packets, helps you plan when to plant and harvest each crop.

Q: Why should you stagger your plantings? A: Staggering your plantings by a few weeks ensures a continuous harvest, preventing all your crops from maturing at the same time. For example, if you plant all your lettuce seeds at once, they will all be ready to harvest around the same time. By staggering the plantings, you’ll have a steady supply of lettuce over a longer period.

Q: What are some easy-to-grow fruits and vegetables for home gardeners? A: Here are eight easy-to-grow fruits and vegetables for home gardeners: 1. Bell Peppers: Start out green but mature to a variety of colors. They get sweeter when allowed to ripen. 2. Blackberries and Raspberries: Caneberries that provide tasty fruits and are easy to prune. 3. Cabbage: Can be planted mid to late summer for a fall harvest. 4. Cucumbers: Grow well in containers with a trellis to keep them healthy. 5. Garlic: Fall-planted garlic produces bigger crops. 6. Strawberries: Flavorful edibles that come back year after year. 7. Tomatoes: Heat-loving plants that can be grown in containers or veggie plots. 8. Zucchini and Squash: Plant seeds directly into the garden and harvest soft-skinned squash when ripe.

Q: How do you grow bell peppers? A: To grow bell peppers, plant them early and allow them to mature fully to get the sweetest flavor. They start out green and can mature to red, orange, yellow, purple, or even chocolate brown. If picked early, they will still change color but won't be as sweet.

Q: What are some tips for growing blackberries and raspberries? A: Blackberries and raspberries, also known as caneberries, are easy to grow and prune. They provide delicious fruits for your family and attract birds and butterflies. Pruning is simple and helps to keep the plants productive.

Q: When is the best time to plant cabbage? A: For most gardeners, planting cabbage seeds in early summer can be challenging due to the heat. Instead, plant cabbage in mid to late summer for a bountiful fall harvest. This cool-loving crop thrives in the cooler temperatures of fall.

Q: How can you grow cucumbers in a small space? A: Cucumbers can be grown in small spaces by planting them in containers and using a trellis to support the vines. This keeps the plants healthier and more productive, making it easier to manage them in tight spaces.

Q: When is the best time to plant garlic for a bigger crop? A: For the best results, plant garlic in the fall. Fall planting allows garlic to develop larger, better-formed bulbs. Make sure the garlic experiences enough chilly weather during growth to encourage the bulbs to separate into cloves.

Q: How do strawberries multiply in a garden? A: Strawberries send out 'runners' that root and create new baby plants, expanding your strawberry patch over time. This self-propagation makes them a long-lasting and productive addition to any garden.

Q: How can tomatoes be grown easily at home? A: Tomatoes are easy to grow in large decorative containers or vegetable plots. Plant them in a sunny location and use plant cages to support their growth, making the plants healthier and harvesting easier. Tomatoes come in many varieties, from large beefsteak tomatoes to tiny cherry tomatoes.

Q: When and how should you plant zucchini and squash? A: Plant zucchini and other squash seeds directly into your garden at the end of the spring planting season. Harvest soft-skinned squash like zucchini when ripe, and store thick-skinned squash for use during the winter. The plants are easy to grow, and even the blossoms are edible.

Q: What are some of the easiest leafy greens to grow? A: Leafy greens like lettuce (Lactuca sativa), kale, silver beet, rocket, and spinach are some of the easiest vegetables to grow. Lettuce, a cool-season crop, can grow year-round, especially in spring and autumn. Loose leaf varieties are better for warmer conditions. It grows best in well-drained soil with organic matter and mulch. Pick-and-eat varieties are great for home gardens. For optimal growth, keep lettuce seedlings moist to prevent bitterness, and pull off the bottom leaves to allow the plant to keep growing.

Q: What are the harvest time, ideal temperatures, and best planting times for leafy greens? A: The harvest time for lettuce and other leafy greens ranges from 2 to 3 months, depending on the type. Lettuce can be grown all year round, with spring and autumn being the best planting times. It needs well-drained soil and organic matter for proper growth, and spacing ranges from 15.24 cm to 45.72 cm depending on the variety.

Q: What are some tips for growing root vegetables like radishes, turnips, and carrots? A: Root vegetables like radishes, turnips, and carrots are easy to grow and are perfect for beginner gardeners. Radishes and turnips grow quickly, while carrots are best planted in late summer to early autumn. These vegetables need full sun and proper spacing for their roots to develop. Don't forget that the tops of radishes and turnips are edible and can be used in dishes like pesto or cooked greens.

Q: What are the harvest time, ideal temperatures, and best planting times for root vegetables? A: The harvest time for root vegetables like radishes and turnips is 2 to 3 months, and early morning is the best time for harvesting. Radishes and turnips can be planted any time of the year, while carrots are best planted in late summer to early autumn. These vegetables need full sun for optimal growth and should be spaced 15.24 cm to 45.72 cm apart.

Q: How do you grow cucumbers and what are their growing requirements? A: Cucumbers are easy to grow, especially during the warm summer months. They require well-drained soil and a trellis or strings to climb on. Slicing cucumbers typically grow 15 to 20 cm, while pickling cucumbers are shorter at 7 to 10 cm. Cucumbers should be planted in spring through mid-summer and need full sun to thrive. They are easy to grow in gardens or containers and can provide instant shade for patios.

Q: What is the harvest time, ideal temperatures, and planting times for cucumbers? A: Cucumbers have a harvest time of 65 to 80 days, depending on the type. They grow best in temperatures above 18°C and should be planted in spring through mid-summer. Cucumbers need adequate spacing between 15.24 cm and 45.72 cm, and they require full sun to thrive.

Q: What are some tips for growing broccoli? A: Broccoli grows best during cooler months and should be sown in summer or autumn. Seeds should be planted in starter pots or trays and transplanted when the seedlings reach about 7 cm tall. Broccoli is susceptible to a soil-borne issue called club root, so avoid planting it in the same spot each year. The plant requires spacing between 30.48 cm to 45.72 cm and grows well in full sun.

Q: What is the harvest time, ideal temperatures, and planting times for broccoli? A: Broccoli's harvest time is 16 to 20 weeks. It grows best in temperatures between 7°C and 30°C and should be planted from October to November and March to April. Spacing should range between 30.48 cm and 45.72 cm to allow for proper growth.

Q: What are the growing requirements for peas and snow peas? A: Peas and snow peas are easy to grow and are ideal for novice gardeners. They grow best in cool weather and should be planted between April and September. These crops need a trellis or strings to climb and grow well in full sun. Their shoots can also be used in salads and stir-fries for a fresh taste. Keep the plants evenly moist to prevent mildew, and avoid planting them during hot weather.

Q: What is the harvest time, ideal temperatures, and planting times for peas and snow peas? A: Peas and snow peas have a harvest time of 65 to 80 days, depending on the type. They thrive in temperatures between 13°C and 21°C and should be planted from April to September. Peas and snow peas need full sun and can grow in partial shade.

Q: What are the best growing practices for strawberries? A: Strawberries are easy to grow and thrive in containers or hanging baskets. When purchasing strawberry plants, look for varieties labeled 'Everbearing' to ensure a longer production season. Strawberries grow well in full sun or partial shade and should be planted year-round, with peaks in early spring and autumn. Protect them from pests like snails and slugs by using coffee grounds or a beer trap.

Q: What is the harvest time, ideal temperatures, and planting times for strawberries? A: Strawberries have peak harvest times in early spring and autumn, but they can continue to produce fruit throughout the year. They thrive in a range of temperatures and can be planted at any time of year. Strawberries should be spaced 15.24 cm apart and can grow well in both sun and partial shade.

Q: What are some easy-to-grow vegetables for beginner gardeners? A: Beginner gardeners can start with easy-to-grow vegetables such as radishes, lettuce, green beans, zucchini, cucumbers, carrots, amaranth, cucamelons, cherry tomatoes, and microgreens. These plants require minimal attention and offer great yields for home gardens.

Q: What makes radishes easy to grow? A: Radishes are easy to grow because they are fast-growing vegetables that can be harvested within a month. They thrive in well-drained soil and only need consistent moisture to develop properly.

Q: How do you grow lettuce? A: Lettuce is one of the easiest vegetables to grow. It is a cool-season vegetable that can be planted in containers or garden beds. It thrives in well-drained soil and requires consistent moisture to produce a generous crop of leaves.

Q: Why are green beans suitable for beginners? A: Green beans are suitable for beginners because they are easy to grow in well-drained soil and sunny locations. They require minimal maintenance, and once planted, they thrive as long as they receive adequate air circulation and sunlight.

Q: What should you know about growing zucchini? A: Zucchini is a warm-weather plant that requires plenty of space as it can spread quickly. It grows well in sunny spots with moist soil. With proper care and trellising, zucchini is a highly productive plant for beginners.

Q: What are the growing requirements for cucumbers? A: Cucumbers are vigorous climbers that require warm weather, fertile soil, and a trellis or support structure. They are water-loving plants that need minimal hands-on effort, apart from occasional pruning to manage their shape.

Q: Why are carrots easy to grow for beginners? A: Carrots are easy to grow because they only need loose, sandy soil for root development and are best sown directly into the garden. With consistent moisture during germination, they yield high-quality crops.

Q: What is unique about growing amaranth? A: Amaranth is a versatile, quick-growing green that stands up to summer heat without bolting. The greens are edible and can be sautéed like spinach. It is easy to cultivate and thrives with regular pruning.

Q: What makes cucamelons an interesting choice for gardeners? A: Cucamelons are unique, easy-to-grow plants that resemble tiny watermelons but taste like cucumbers. They are vigorous climbers and fruit consistently until the first frost. Cucamelons are a fun addition to any garden and can be added to salads for a crunchy texture.

Q: What makes Sungold cherry tomatoes a good beginner plant? A: Sungold cherry tomatoes are a great choice for beginners because they are disease-resistant and produce a continuous crop of sweet, golden fruits. They are easy to freeze for later use and thrive in most garden settings.

Q: How do you grow microgreens? A: Microgreens are one of the easiest crops to grow, as they can be cultivated indoors or outdoors. They are ready to harvest within 10 to 14 days and provide fresh, nutritious greens that are packed with flavor.
Q: Is basil safe for cats? A: Yes, basil is safe for cats.
Q: Is coriander safe for cats? A: Yes, coriander is safe for cats.
Q: Can cats eat rosemary? A: Yes, cats can eat rosemary, and it is safe for them.
Q: Is sage safe to grow with cats around? A: Yes, sage is safe to grow if you have cats.
Q: Is thyme safe for cats? A: Yes, thyme is safe for cats.
Q: Is oregano safe for cats? A: No, oregano is not safe for cats.
Q: Should cats eat chives? A: No, chives are not safe for cats and should be kept out of their reach.
Q: Is tarragon safe for cats? A: No, tarragon is not safe for cats.
Q: Is mint safe for cats? A: No, mint is not safe for cats.

Q: What are the benefits of catnip for cats? A: Catnip can help relieve stress, reduce itching, and soothe the skin. However, it should be introduced slowly as some cats can act overly excited or experience diarrhea and vomiting if given too much.
Q: Why might cat thyme be a beneficial herb for cats? A: Cat thyme is beneficial for cats if they can tolerate the smell, offering similar effects as catnip.
Q: What benefits does calendula provide for cats? A: Calendula can help soothe itchy skin, heal wounds, and reduce bruising. However, only the flowers are safe for cats.

Q: What makes dandelion a beneficial herb for cats? A: Dandelion can help with liver support, digestion, allergies, kidney stones, inflammation, blood pressure regulation, blood sugar control, arthritis, and more. It is high in vitamins and minerals, and both the leaves and root offer different benefits.
Q: What are the benefits of eyebright for cats? A: Eyebright may help with breathing issues, constant sneezing, itchy eyes, and nasal problems. It is also suitable for immune support.

Q: What are the similarities between eyebright and echinacea? A: Echinacea has similar properties to eyebright, helping with respiratory problems and immune support, but it is often easier to find and more popular.

Q: How can goldenseal benefit cats? A: Goldenseal can be used as a natural disinfectant for wounds and may help reduce swelling around the eyes. It may also reduce gas, treat ulcers, and help regulate blood pressure and heart rate. However, it should not be given to kittens as it can cause brain damage.

Q: What are the benefits of liquorice root for cats? A: Liquorice root has anti-inflammatory properties, helps with digestive issues, soothes itchy skin, and supports the immune system. It is particularly beneficial for cats with arthritis.

Q: Why is parsley a good herb for cats? A: Parsley helps the body detox, fights infections, supports the urinary tract, relieves inflammation, and is high in iron, beta-carotene, and chlorophyll. It is particularly good for cats with kidney issues, but it should be introduced in small amounts to avoid diarrhea and vomiting.

Q: How does valerian affect cats? A: Valerian can help relax cats, improve sleep, reduce aggression, and encourage playful behavior. It is particularly effective in providing enrichment and reducing boredom.
Q: Can cats eat bananas? A: Yes, cats can eat bananas. These are a good source of vitamins B6 and C, potassium, and carbohydrates. Offer sliced bananas that are either fresh or frozen.

Q: Can cats eat watermelon? A: Yes, cats can eat a small portion of watermelon flesh on occasion. Watermelon flesh is safe for cats to eat, but the rind and seeds should be avoided. The occasional thin, pale seed from a 'seedless' watermelon should not cause harm if accidentally ingested, but a small portion of rind may lead to bowel cleansing.

Q: Can cats eat strawberries? A: Yes, cats can eat strawberries in small amounts. Although strawberries provide vitamin C, folate, potassium, and manganese, as well as antioxidants and fiber, the benefits are not noticeable in cats because they cannot safely consume large amounts. Be sure to remove the stems and leaves, then wash the strawberries before cutting them into small pieces.

Q: Can cats eat blueberries, raspberries, cranberries, and blackberries? A: Yes, cats can eat blueberries, blackberries, raspberries, and cranberries. These berries are high in antioxidants, flavonoids, fiber, and vitamins A, C, K, and E. Be sure to cut each one into bite-size portions before offering to avoid choking hazards.

Q: Can cats eat apples? A: Yes, cats can eat apples. The flesh of apples is high in calcium, vitamin C, vitamin K, and pectin, and the skin is high in phytonutrients. Cats can get the same health benefits from apples as humans do. Offer small slices or cubes with the flesh and peel, but avoid the stems and seeds.

Q: Can cats eat mangos? A: Yes, cats can eat mangos. This sweet fruit is rich in fiber, vitamin C, vitamin B6, and vitamin A. Small cubes or slices of mango flesh are allowed, but avoid the skin and seed.

Q: Can cats eat pineapple? A: Yes, cats can eat pineapple. This tropical treat is high in fructose and contains several vitamins (A, B6, folate, C) and minerals (magnesium and potassium). Fresh pineapple is preferred over canned, which is often packed in a sugary syrup that may contain preservatives. Be sure to remove the leaves, thorns, and rind completely before sharing with your feline friend.

Q: Can cats eat cantaloupe? A: Yes, cats can eat cantaloupe. Cantaloupe is a good source of vitamin C, beta carotene, fiber, and antioxidants. This relatively low-calorie fruit is often a favorite of felines because the scent that cantaloupes produce mimics the scent of the proteins in meat. Offer small cubes or slices of the flesh, but avoid the rind.

Q: Can cats eat fruit snacks? A: No, cats should not eat fruit snacks. These gummy snacks are made from fruit juice concentrate without the fruit fiber, and some have more sugar than candy, making them especially unhealthy for cats.

Q: How much fruit can a cat have? A: Limit fruits and other treats to 2% of your cat’s diet. This is about a 1-inch portion each day. Fruits are best given as an alternative to cat treats, especially when weight loss is desired. They may be offered as a fresh or frozen treat that is cut into small pieces. They should be given separately from their regular pet food. If your cat is unable to comfortably digest the fruit, you may see signs of digestive upset (upset stomach), such as vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. Due to the high sugar content, diabetic cats should not be given fruit.

Q: Which other fruits are safe for cats? A: These fruits are also safe for cats to eat in small quantities: apricots, cucumber, honeydew, kiwi, nectarines, and pears. Be sure to remove the seeds, stems, pits, cores, and rinds before feeding them to your cat.

Q: Which fruits are not safe for cats? A: Grapes and raisins can cause serious digestive issues, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, and even acute kidney failure in cats. Additionally, the oils and compounds in citrus fruits like oranges, lemons, and limes can cause digestive irritation, vomiting, diarrhea, or even central nervous system depression.

Q: Which other human foods are safe for cats? A: Your cat can also enjoy these foods safely, in moderation: artichokes, asparagus, beans, broccoli, cabbage, carrot (cut into small bites to avoid choking hazards), cauliflower, celery (cut into small bites to avoid choking hazards), coconut, eggplant, ginger, green beans, lettuce, olives, peas, peppers, pumpkin (avoid seeds, stems, pits, rinds), sweet potato, and winter squash.
Q: Which human foods are toxic for cats? A: Do not give these foods to your cat: chives, garlic, green tomatoes, leeks, wild mushrooms, onions, rhubarb, and most seeds, stems, pits, rinds, and roots.

Q: Can dogs eat apples? A: Yes, dogs can eat apples. Apples are an excellent source of vitamins A and C, as well as fiber for your dog. They are low in protein and fat, making them the perfect snack for senior dogs. Just be sure to remove the seeds and core first. Try them frozen for an icy warm weather snack. You can also find it as an ingredient in apple-flavored dog treats.

Q: Can dogs eat avocado? A: No, dogs should avoid avocado. While avocado may be a healthy snack for dog owners, it should not be given to dogs. The pit, skin, and leaves of avocados contain persin, a toxin that often causes vomiting and diarrhea in dogs. The fleshy inside of the avocado fruit doesn’t have as much persin as the rest of the plant, but it still can be too much for dogs to handle. Avocado flesh is also high in fat, which can cause gastrointestinal upset or contribute to health conditions like pancreatitis if too much is consumed.

Q: Can dogs eat bananas? A: Yes, dogs can eat bananas. In moderation, bananas are a great low-calorie treat for dogs. They’re high in potassium, vitamins, biotin, fiber, and copper. They are low in cholesterol and sodium, but because of their high sugar content, bananas should be given as a treat, not part of your dog’s main diet.

Q: Can dogs eat blueberries? A: Yes, dogs can eat blueberries. Blueberries are a superfood rich in antioxidants, which prevent cell damage in humans and canines alike. They’re packed with fiber and phytochemicals as well. Blueberries make for a healthy snack and are even used in blueberry dog treats.

Q: Can dogs eat cantaloupe? A: Yes, cantaloupe is safe for dogs. Cantaloupe is packed with nutrients, low in calories, and a great source of water and fiber. It is, however, high in sugar, so should be shared in moderation, especially for dogs who are overweight or have diabetes.

Q: Can dogs eat cherries? A: No, dogs should not eat cherries. With the exception of the fleshy fruit around the seed, cherry plants contain cyanide and are toxic to dogs. Cyanide disrupts cellular oxygen transport, which means that your dog’s blood cells can’t get enough oxygen.

Q: Can dogs eat cranberries? A: Yes, cranberries are safe for dogs to eat. Both cranberries and dried cranberries are safe to feed to dogs in small quantities. However, moderation is key, as too many cranberries can lead to an upset stomach.

Q: Can dogs eat cucumbers? A: Yes, dogs can eat cucumbers. Cucumbers are especially good for overweight dogs, as they hold little to no carbohydrates or fat, and they are full of satiating hydration. They’re loaded with vitamins K, C, and B1, as well as potassium, copper, magnesium, and biotin.

Q: Can dogs eat grapes? A: No, dogs should never eat grapes. Grapes and raisins (dried grapes) have proved to be very toxic for dogs no matter the dog’s breed, sex, or age. In fact, grapes are so toxic that they can lead to acute sudden kidney failure.

Q: Can dogs eat mangoes? A: Yes, dogs can eat mangoes. This sweet and juicy tropical treat is packed with four different vitamins: A, B6, C, and E. Mangoes also have potassium and both beta-carotene and alpha-carotene. Just remember to remove the hard pit first, as it contains small amounts of cyanide and can become a choking hazard.

Q: Can dogs eat oranges? A: Yes, dogs can eat oranges. Oranges are an excellent source of vitamin C, potassium, and fiber, and in small quantities, the juicy flesh of an orange can be a tasty treat for your dog. Vets recommend tossing the orange peel and only offering your dog the flesh of the orange, minus any seeds.

Q: Can dogs eat peaches? A: Yes, peaches are safe for dogs to eat. Small amounts of cut-up fresh or frozen peaches are a great source of fiber and vitamin A, but the pit contains cyanide. As long as you completely cut the flesh away from the peach pit, then fresh peach flesh can be a great summer treat.

Q: Can dogs eat pears? A: Yes, dogs can eat pears. Pears are a great snack because they’re high in copper, vitamins C and K, and fiber. If you’re sharing pears with your dog, just be sure to cut the pear flesh into bite-size chunks and remove the pit and seeds first, as the seeds contain traces of cyanide.

Q: Can dogs eat pineapple? A: Yes, pineapple is safe for dogs to eat. A few chunks of pineapple are a great sweet treat for dogs, as long as the prickly outside peel and crown are removed first. The tropical fruit is full of vitamins, minerals, and fiber. It also contains bromelain, an enzyme that makes it easier for dogs to absorb proteins.

Q: Can dogs eat pumpkin? A: Yes, pure pumpkin is a healthy food for dogs. Pumpkin is full of antioxidants, but its superpower is that it works to relieve both diarrhea and constipation in dogs. If you’re buying canned pumpkin, always choose 100% pumpkin puree, or you can also roast pumpkin in the oven yourself and feed the peeled pumpkin flesh to your dog.

Q: Can dogs eat raspberries? A: Yes, dogs can eat raspberries. Raspberries are safe for dogs in moderation. They contain antioxidants that are great for dogs and have anti-inflammatory properties, which can help aging joints. However, they do contain small amounts of xylitol, so limit your dog to no more than eight ounces at a time.

Q: Can dogs eat strawberries? A: Yes, dogs can eat strawberries. Strawberries are full of fiber and vitamin C. Along with that, they also contain an enzyme that can help whiten your dog’s teeth as they eat them. Like all fruits, strawberries contain natural sugar, so offer them in moderation.

Q: Can dogs eat tomatoes? A: No, dogs should avoid tomatoes. While the ripened flesh of the tomato fruit is generally safe for dogs, the green parts of the tomato plant contain a toxic substance called solanine. A dog would need to eat a large amount of the tomato plant to make them sick, but it’s better to avoid tomatoes entirely.

Q: Can dogs eat watermelon? A: Yes, dogs can eat watermelon. Watermelon is full of vitamins A, B-6, and C, as well as potassium. Watermelon is 92 percent water, so it’s a great way to help keep your dog hydrated on hot summer days. Be sure to remove the rind and seeds first, as they can cause intestinal blockage.

Q: What are the main types of green beans? A: Green beans come in two main types: bush beans and pole beans. Bush beans grow compactly to about two feet tall and do not require support, while pole beans grow as climbing vines that can reach 10 to 15 feet tall and require a trellis or staking for support.

Q: What are some of the different colors of green beans? A: In addition to the typical green variety, green beans can also come in other colors such as purple, red, yellow, and streaked varieties. These colorful varieties add visual appeal to your garden and meals.

Q: What is the difference between bush beans and pole beans? A: Bush beans grow to about two feet tall and do not require support structures, making them easier to manage. Pole beans, on the other hand, grow as climbing vines that can reach 10 to 15 feet tall and need a trellis or staking to support their growth. Both types have their advantages and disadvantages, depending on your gardening preferences.

Q: What are the advantages of growing bush beans? A: The advantages of growing bush beans include their compact size, which makes them easy to grow in smaller spaces or containers. They require less maintenance because they don't need support structures like pole beans. Bush beans also produce beans relatively quickly, within 50 to 55 days.

Q: What are the advantages of growing pole beans? A: Pole beans have several advantages, including higher yields and longer production periods. They can continue producing beans for a month or two if harvested regularly, and they are typically more disease-resistant compared to bush beans. However, they require support structures like a trellis or staking to grow properly.

Q: How long does it take for bush beans and pole beans to mature? A: Bush beans take about 50 to 55 days to mature, while pole beans require slightly more time, taking about 55 to 65 days to produce beans. The time to maturity can vary slightly depending on the variety and growing conditions.

Q: How should you plant bush beans to ensure a continuous harvest? A: To ensure a continuous harvest of bush beans, stagger your plantings every two weeks. Since bush beans often produce their beans all at once, planting in intervals will allow you to harvest fresh beans over a longer period instead of having a single large harvest.

Q: How long will pole beans produce beans? A: Pole beans will continue producing beans for about a month or two if you regularly harvest them. Their vines grow throughout the season, allowing for an extended harvest period compared to bush beans, which tend to produce all at once.

Q: What type of soil do beans grow best in? A: Beans grow best in well-draining soil with normal fertility and an acidic to neutral pH range of 6.0 to 7.0. They don't typically need supplemental fertilizer because they fix their own nitrogen in the soil. However, if your soil is particularly poor, it’s a good idea to amend it with aged manure or compost before planting.

Q: Do beans need supplemental fertilizer? A: Beans don’t usually need supplemental fertilizer because they have the ability to fix their own nitrogen in the soil. However, if your soil is particularly poor, you should amend it with aged manure or compost in the fall before planting, or about a week prior to planting in the spring.

Q: Why should supports for pole beans be set up before planting? A: Supports for pole beans, such as trellises or stakes, should be set up before planting because beans do not like having their roots disturbed. Setting up supports beforehand helps avoid damaging the plants later on.

Q: When is the best time to plant beans? A: The best time to plant beans is after the last spring frost date, when the soil has warmed to at least 55°F (12°C). Planting too early in cold, moist soil can delay germination and increase the risk of seeds rotting. Direct-seeding beans outdoors is the most effective method for growing them.

Q: How can you warm the soil before planting beans? A: To warm the soil before planting beans, you can place black plastic or landscaping fabric over your garden beds. This helps raise the soil temperature, allowing you to sow seeds sooner after the last frost.

Q: Should green bean seeds be started indoors? A: No, green bean seeds should not be started indoors. Because of their fragile roots, they may not survive transplanting. Additionally, beans grow quickly, so there's no significant advantage to starting them indoors.

Q: How should you plant bush beans? A: To plant bush beans, sow the seeds 1 inch (2.5 cm) deep and 2 inches (5 cm) apart. Space the rows 18 inches (45 cm) apart to give the plants enough room to grow. If your soil is sandy, you can plant the seeds slightly deeper, but be careful not to plant them too deep, as the seedlings may struggle to emerge.

Q: How should you plant pole beans? A: To plant pole beans, sow the seeds 1 inch (2.5 cm) deep around the supports, such as trellises, stakes, or other structures. It's important to set up the supports before planting to avoid disturbing the plants' fragile roots. You can also plant pole beans slightly deeper in sandy soils but avoid planting them too deep to ensure the seedlings can emerge.

Q: How can you create a teepee support for pole beans? A: To create a teepee support for pole beans, tie three or four (or more) 7-foot-long (about 2.1 meters) bamboo poles or straight branches together at the top and spread the legs in a circle. Plant three or four seeds around each pole. As the vines grow, train them to climb up the poles. For added stability, you can wrap string or wire around the poles about halfway up to give the vines more support.

Q: What is another easy support option for pole beans? A: Another easy support option for pole beans is a 'cattle panel,' which is a portable section of wire fence that measures 16 feet (about 4.9 meters) long and 5 feet (1.5 meters) tall. The beans will climb the fence easily, and you'll have an easier time harvesting without needing to bend or contort to reach the beans.

Q: How can you ensure a continued harvest of beans throughout the summer? A: To ensure a continued harvest of beans throughout the summer, sow seeds every 2 weeks. If you plan to be away and unable to harvest, skip a planting, as beans will continue to grow and need to be harvested regularly. Regular planting ensures a steady supply of fresh beans over the growing season.

Q: Why is crop rotation important when planting beans? A: Practicing crop rotation is important when planting beans to avoid the build-up of pests and diseases in one spot. By rotating crops and planting them in different areas each year, you help maintain the health of the soil and reduce the risk of issues that can affect your plants.

Q: How should you mulch and water bean plants? A: Mulch the soil around bean plants to retain moisture and keep their shallow roots cool. Water the plants regularly, about 2 inches (5 cm) per square foot each week. Make sure the soil is well-drained, and water on sunny days to prevent the foliage from remaining soaked, which could encourage disease. If beans are not watered well, they will stop flowering.

Q: Can green beans be grown in containers? A: Yes, green beans can be grown in containers. For bush beans, use an 8-inch-deep (20 cm), 8-inch-wide (20 cm) container for one plant. For pole beans, a 5-gallon (19-liter) pot can hold up to three plants, but you will need to provide support either in or just outside the container. Fill the container with potting mix and rich compost, and make sure to direct-seed the beans after all danger of frost has passed.

Q: How should you plant green beans in a container? A: To plant green beans in a container, sow two beans into each hole about 1 to 1 1/2 inches (2.5 to 3.8 cm) deep. After germination, eliminate the weaker seedling by cutting its stem, as having two plants in one hole will cause neither to thrive. Ensure the soil is warm (55°F or higher) and moist for optimal germination.

Q: How much sun and water do container-grown green beans need? A: Green beans grown in containers need 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day. Water the plants whenever the soil is dry, ensuring you water to a depth of 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5 cm) to keep the roots hydrated. Consistent watering is key to healthy growth and a good bean yield.

Q: What type of fertilizer should you use for green beans in containers? A: For green beans in containers, use a low-nitrogen fertilizer (such as a 5-10-10 formula) diluted to half-strength. Apply it at planting time and again when the plants begin to flower. Avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers, as they promote excessive foliage growth and reduce bean production. A side dressing of compost or aged manure halfway through the growing season is a good alternative.

Q: How should you care for pole beans when they reach the top of their support? A: When pole beans reach the top of their support, pinch off the tops of the vines. This will force the plants to redirect their energy into producing more pods instead of continuing to grow upwards. This practice can help increase your bean harvest.

Q: What should you do if your area experiences high heat while growing beans? A: In high heat, cover your young bean plants with row covers to protect them from excessive temperatures. Hot weather can cause the blossoms to drop from the plants, which would reduce your overall bean harvest. Row covers help keep the plants cool and mitigate the effects of extreme heat.

Q: What are Chinese (Asian) long beans? A: Chinese (Asian) long beans, also known as yardlong or asparagus beans, are slender beans that grow 1 to 2 feet (30 to 60 cm) long. These are all pole beans and include varieties such as 'Orient Wonder,' 'Red Noodle,' and 'Yardlong.' They are highly productive and grow well with support.

Q: What are French green beans (haricots verts)? A: French green beans, also known as filet beans or haricots verts, are thin and tender with 3- to 5-inch (7.6 to 12.7 cm) pods. Varieties to try include 'Calima,' 'Masai,' and 'Maxibel.' For container gardening, 'Mascotte' is a compact variety that grows well in small spaces.

Q: What are Italian/Romano beans? A: Italian or Romano beans are wide, flat beans with pods that can grow 6 to 8 inches (15 to 20 cm) long, even in the hottest summer weather. Recommended varieties include 'Early Bush Italian,' the extra-large-pod 'Jumbo,' and 'Roma II.' These beans are typically bush varieties.

Q: What are purple beans? A: Purple beans have deep purple, 5- to 6-inch (12.7 to 15.2 cm) pods that turn green when cooked. Recommended varieties include 'Amethyst,' 'Royal Burgundy,' and 'Velour,' all of which are bush types.

Q: What are snap beans? A: Snap beans, also known as string or stringless beans, produce slender 5- to 7-inch (12.7 to 17.8 cm) pods. Varieties to try include 'Blue Lake 274' (bush), heirloom 'Kentucky Wonder' (bush or pole), and 'Provider' (bush).

Q: What are yellow wax beans? A: Yellow wax beans produce 5- to 7-inch (12.7 to 17.8 cm) pods and have a milder flavor than green varieties. Some popular varieties include stringless 'Cherokee' (bush), classic 'Golden Wax' (bush), and 'Monte Gusto' (pole).

Q: What are some good green bean varieties for containers? A: Several green bean varieties grow well in containers, including: 'White Dixie Butterpea' (16- to 24-inch-tall plants, good for hot climates), 'Derby' (7-inch-long pods on 18-inch plants), 'Mascotte' (prolific 5- to 6-inch fruit on 16- to 18-inch plants), 'Topcrop' (heirloom with 6- to 7-inch pods on 15- to 18-inch plants), 'Hestia' (12- to 14-inch-tall dwarf runner bean), and 'Rattlesnake' (heirloom with vines up to 10 feet long and green pods with purple speckles).

Q: What is Phaseolus lunatus ‘White Dixie Butterpea’? A: Phaseolus lunatus ‘White Dixie Butterpea’ is a compact lima bean variety that grows 16 to 24 inches (40 to 61 cm) tall. Each pod contains three to four small lima beans, and it performs well in hot weather.

Q: What is Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Derby’? A: Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Derby’ is a tender green bean variety with 7-inch (17.8 cm) long pods that grow on 18-inch (45.7 cm) tall plants. It is resistant to bean common mosaic virus, making it a reliable option for gardeners.

Q: What is Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Mascotte’? A: Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Mascotte’ is a prolific green bean variety ideal for containers. It produces 5- to 6-inch (12.7 to 15.2 cm) pods on 16- to 18-inch (40 to 45.7 cm) tall plants and is resistant to anthracnose, bean common mosaic virus, and halo blight.

Q: What is Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Topcrop’? A: Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Topcrop’ is a vigorous heirloom green bean variety that produces a heavy crop of 6- to 7-inch (15 to 17.8 cm) pods on 15- to 18-inch (38 to 45.7 cm) tall bushes. It is resistant to bean common mosaic virus.

Q: What is Phaseolus coccineus ‘Hestia’? A: Phaseolus coccineus ‘Hestia’ is a dwarf runner bean variety that grows 12 to 14 inches (30 to 35.6 cm) tall and produces 8-inch (20 cm) pods. The beans can be harvested fresh or left to dry on the plant for use in soups and stews.

Q: What is Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Rattlesnake’? A: Phaseolus vulgaris ‘Rattlesnake’ is an heirloom green bean variety with vines that can grow up to 10 feet (3 meters) long. It produces 8- to 10-inch (20 to 25.4 cm) green pods with purple speckles and is both heat-tolerant and drought-resistant.

Q: When is the best time to harvest green beans? A: The best time to harvest green beans is in the morning when their sugar levels are at their highest. Picking them early ensures the best flavor and texture. Harvest beans young and tender, before the seeds inside have fully developed.

Q: How often should you pick green beans? A: Green beans should be picked every day. The more you pick, the more beans the plant will produce. Regular harvesting encourages continuous growth throughout the season.

Q: How do you know when green beans are ready to be picked? A: Green beans are ready to be picked when they are young, firm, and about as thick as a pencil. Look for firm, sizable pods that snap easily when bent. If you notice the seeds inside the pod bulging, the beans are past their peak and will taste tougher.

Q: What is the best method for picking green beans? A: To pick green beans, either snap or cut the beans off the plant. Be careful not to tear or damage the plant itself, as this could impact future bean production. Fresh beans should snap easily when broken.

Q: How should you store freshly harvested green beans? A: Store freshly harvested green beans in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Keep in mind that beans will toughen over time, even when stored properly.

Q: What are other ways to preserve green beans besides refrigerating? A: In addition to refrigerating, green beans can be preserved by blanching and freezing them immediately after harvesting. You can also can or pickle green beans for long-term storage. These methods help retain the beans' flavor and texture over time.

Q: What items does a gardener need to get started? A: In terms of tools, a hand trowel is essential, and it is important to choose one that feels comfortable in your hand as it will be used frequently. A hand fork is also crucial, along with a good pair of secateurs for pruning. To be prepared year-round, a garden fork and spade are recommended, ensuring they are not too heavy to handle. A watering can is a must, ideally one with a detachable fine rose to avoid drenching young plants. Gardening gloves are important if you want to keep your hands clean. Compost is necessary, but choose the right type, and liquid fertilizer can be useful to give plants an instant boost throughout the year.

Q: How to get started in the garden if you’re feeling a bit overwhelmed? A: If you have moved into a new home or have a blank garden space, live with the garden for a while to observe how the sun moves across it. This helps in deciding where to spend time, place seating or play areas, and determine the best spots for plants to thrive. Work on one area at a time to avoid feeling overwhelmed. Start by picking a south or west-facing spot and marking out a border, ideally a meter deep. If the border is by a fence, consider planting climbers like Clematis, Sweet Peas, or Honeysuckle for a backdrop of flowers and foliage. Enjoy the process and take your time—gardening is great for both physical and mental health. Starting small, such as with a container or a window box of herbs, can build confidence.

Q: How to prepare a garden for planting? A: Clear away winter debris and remove weeds to create a blank space. Once cleared, add compost or organic matter to prepare the beds, and dress the top with plant food to ensure your garden thrives. This sets the stage for planting.

Q: What are the best plants for a beginner? A: Cottage garden plants are cost-effective and flower annually, attracting beneficial insects. Classic hardy annuals like Nigella, Centaurea, and Calendula are easy to grow and provide long-lasting summer blooms. Bedding plants like Pansies and Violas are also beginner-friendly and flourish in summer, as long as they are watered regularly. Sunflowers are simple to grow and add brightness to any garden. For growing produce, strawberries are rewarding and great for involving children in gardening.

Q: What flowers or plants would you recommend to create a beautiful garden in a limited space? A: Hanging baskets and plant pots are excellent for small spaces and add vibrant color. Patio roses can add a splash of summer color to sunny spots. For narrow balconies, lightweight saddle pots, troughs, and vertical growing systems attached to railings or walls can maximize space. Even small urban gardens can benefit from raised beds for growing a variety of vegetables, while grow sacks work well for patios, especially for potatoes. A sunny windowsill can host herbs and small vegetables like salad greens, radishes, and cherry tomatoes for fresh produce.

Q: Are there any common beginners’ mistakes to watch out for? A: Choosing the correct compost can be challenging, so it’s essential to research the types available and find the one that best suits your garden. Overwatering is another common mistake—plants may not need watering during wetter months, but in summer, they may require daily attention. Regularly deadheading flowers with secateurs keeps plants looking healthy and encourages new blooms. Also, pay attention to where plants naturally grow—if they seed in a spot and thrive, it’s best to leave them there rather than moving them.

Q: Why should you grow vegetables at home? A: You may want to grow vegetables at home for many reasons. Some people raise vegetables for the exercise and personal enjoyment they get from gardening. Other gardeners grow vegetables because they are especially particular about the freshness, flavor and texture of the vegetables they eat. Still others are concerned about the variety and amount of vegetables needed for balanced nutrition. Some people even have vegetable gardens because they want their family to have fresh vegetables and regular shopping is expensive or inconvenient. Despite the many reasons people garden, we cannot evaluate in monetary terms how much gardening contributes to our health and well-being. Surely, we reduce our overall cost of living by avoiding the expense and misery of poor health and sickness due to poor nutrition and inadequate exercise. Thus, gardening can add to our lives in many ways—it’s more than just fresh food on the table. For more information about gardening, preparing vegetables, the nutritional value of vegetables, and freezing, canning and storing vegetables at home, check the reference list at the end of this booklet for publications available at your county Extension office.

Q: Where should you grow vegetables in a home garden. A: Put your home vegetable garden in a place that has well-drained soil and is convenient to the house. The garden should not be shaded by buildings, trees or shrubs—vegetables need full sunlight throughout the day to grow well. Trees and shrubs close by also compete with garden plants for moisture and fertilizer. If space is limited, select crops for your garden that use little space—such as bush and pole snap beans, beet, cabbage, carrot, chard, lettuce, onion, parsley, pepper, radish, spinach, and tomato. Avoid large or vining crops such as pumpkin, squash and sweet corn. These vegetables do not produce as much for the amount of space they occupy.

Q: How can you create an ornamental vegetable garden? A: Certain vegetables and cultivars make attractive as well as edible displays. You can plant an ornamental vegetable garden in the front or side yard or even add vegetables to your flower garden. For your ornamental garden, choose crops that have a variety of colors, textures and sizes. Crops such as beans, cabbage, chard, chives, eggplant, flowering kale, leaf lettuce, okra, parsley, peppers and sunflowers work well. You can also use cucumbers, herbs and tomatoes. The ornamental vegetable garden on page 3 shows one of many ways you could plan such a garden. This garden would look particularly nice on a gently sloping hillside. Theme gardens—such as a salad bowl garden or a children’s garden—are also easy.

Q: What are the best vegetables for growing indoors? A: Few vegetables grow well indoors without special lighting, but you can get good results with chives, parsley, rhubarb (forced) and witloof chicory (French endive, forced).
Q: How can you grow chives indoors? A: Transplant small clumps of chive from the garden into containers and harvest leaves.

Q: What is the process for growing parsley indoors? A: Start a parsley plant from seeds sown outside in a pot or other container around August 1. Move the plant indoors before heavy frosts and harvest the leaves.

Q: How do you grow rhubarb indoors? A: To grow rhubarb indoors, move rhubarb clumps (crowns) into a warm, dark basement after they have been thoroughly chilled outside, usually about the middle of November. Keep the crowns under moist straw. Harvest rhubarb leaf stalks (petioles) when they are about 12 to 15 inches long.

Q: How do I know what I need to do in my garden each weekend? A: Few domestic gardens need work every weekend as they are often self-sustaining. Generally, prune old growth to promote new growth, feed plants when transitioning to spring and summer, pull weeds while they’re small, and plant late if necessary. Mulching regularly is also beneficial.

Q: What is the difference between a perennial and an annual plant? A: Annuals complete their life cycle in one year, growing quickly and needing good light. Perennials return every year, often die back in winter, and store energy in their roots. They may take years to mature and may not flower from seed until their second year or later.

Q: Should I use seeds or plants for my garden? A: Both are useful. Seeds are cheaper, more environmentally friendly, and adapt to the soil as they germinate. Plants offer instant results but may come in plastic pots and require more resources. Growing from seeds can be rewarding and hooks gardeners into the process, whereas buying perennials in pots can save time.

Q: When should I prune my plants? A: There is no strict rule for pruning. Many plants evolved to respond well to pruning due to herbivore pressure. Plants with thorns or soft leaves often tolerate hard pruning, while plants with essential oils should be pruned on soft growth only. If unsure, consult a reliable pruning guide.

Q: How do I determine the type of soil in my garden? A: Dig a hole, pour a bucket of water into it, and check drainage time. If it drains in under 10 minutes, the soil is free-draining; over 20 minutes indicates clay content. Rubbing a pinch of soil between your fingers helps identify its type: gritty indicates sand, smooth indicates clay, and dark material indicates organic matter.

Q: Should I grow plants in pots or in the ground? A: Growing in pots or the ground depends on space, resources, and the plant’s size. Large plants need big pots and frequent watering if potted. Plants with soft, large leaves require regular watering in pots, whereas plants adapted to dry climates can thrive in pots with less water. Pots can also be used to control soil conditions.

Q: What is the difference between compost and mulch? A: Compost is finer, rotted organic material used to enrich soil. Mulch consists of larger particles that decompose slower, making it ideal for paths and weed suppression. Leaf mould is a type of compost made from decomposed leaves and is excellent for plants that thrive in fungal-dominated soil.

Q: Should I make my own compost and how? A: If you have space, composting is beneficial. Use a mix of greens (e.g., leafy matter, food scraps) and browns (e.g., twigs, cardboard). Compost bins should be placed directly on soil to allow decomposers to access them. Regular composting enriches soil quality and helps reduce waste.

Q: What does ‘full sun’ mean for plants? A: ‘Full sun’ refers to areas that receive over six hours of direct sunlight per day at midsummer. Although the sun is lower in winter, the spot will still be a good choice for sun-loving plants.

Q: What does partial shade mean for plants? A: Partial shade is defined as areas receiving less than six hours of sunlight during midsummer. Deep shade is darker, often under conifers. While most plants tolerate some shade, they may need additional feeding and watering. Mulching with well-rotted compost helps retain moisture in shaded areas.

Q: Do bulbs return annually and do they spread? A: Some bulbs like crocus, hyacinth, and narcissus reliably return and can naturalise over time. Deadhead spent flowers to direct energy back into the bulb and allow leaves to yellow to nourish it. Whether to lift and store or let them spread is up to you.

Q: What should I do with slugs in my garden? A: Slugs are decomposers and part of the ecosystem, serving as food for wildlife. Building habitats for natural predators, like hedgehogs and birds, can help control their population. Throwing slugs over the fence is ineffective as they may return.

Q: Can I grow vegetables on a windowsill? A: Yes, microgreens are ideal for windowsill gardening. Sow seeds densely in a seed tray and harvest them as young plants after the first true leaves develop. Good options include rocket, mustard greens, peas, and sunflower shoots.

Q: When should plants be fertilised? A: Ideally, plants in soil with annual mulching do not need additional feeding. However, plants in containers or nutrient-heavy crops like tomatoes may benefit from fertilisation to ensure healthy growth.

Q: What does ‘dividing’ plants mean? A: Dividing plants means taking a mature plant and splitting it to create new ones. This may involve separating plantlets or dividing clumps, like chives or rhubarb. Dividing is often done when the plant is dormant, like in winter for rhubarb.

Q: Which vegetables are easiest for beginners to grow? A: Tomatoes are a classic beginner’s crop, offering easy care and rewarding yields. Leafy greens like lettuce, kale, and herbs like parsley and chives are also simple to grow. They can be harvested at various stages and tolerate some shade.

Q: How do I know when my plant needs repotting? A: Signs of needing repotting include wilting, quick-drying soil, roots growing from drainage holes, and yellowing leaves due to nutrient depletion. To repot, loosen the soil around the pot and move the plant to a larger container with fresh compost.

Q: How do I identify and manage weeds? A: ‘Weed’ is a flexible term; wild plants can be beneficial. Learning local flora helps decide which to remove or keep. Persistent weeds like thistles and bindweed should be managed early, while plants like dandelions can support pollinators and be left.

Q: How can I maintain a nice lawn? A: To maintain a lawn, mow regularly during the growing season and repair thin areas in spring by aerating, reseeding, and removing large weeds. Reducing lawn size can help conserve water and support wildlife.

Q: How can I create a meadow garden in a small space? A: Small gardens can include a meadow section. Choose a sunny spot, sow wildflower seeds suitable for your soil, and maintain paths. Plug plants like cowslips and speedwells add variety and will flower under high mower settings.

Q: When is a plant considered ‘established’? A: A plant is established when its roots have settled and new leaves appear. This usually takes one to two years for perennials and shrubs. If a plant still requires regular watering after this period, it may be in an unsuitable location.

Q: What tasks are essential for low-maintenance gardening? A: Plant low-maintenance shrubs like skimmia or cistus, which require little care once established. Regularly trim borders and mulch in spring and autumn to reduce weeds. Persistent weeds like bindweed and bramble need manual removal.

Q: How did people manage gardening before the internet? A: Observation was key; noticing plant growth and responses to changes helped gardeners learn. Asking experienced gardeners and reading books were valuable resources. Patience and careful attention were essential.

Q: What does ‘bright, indirect sunlight’ mean indoors? A: Bright indirect sunlight refers to reflected, non-harsh light found near windows that receive direct sunlight. A simple method to determine light levels is by observing shadows: well-defined shadows indicate bright light.

Q: Which houseplants need more water? A: Cacti and succulents store water and thrive in dry conditions. Tropical plants with large leaves need frequent watering. Check soil moisture by inserting a finger; if the top inch is dry, it’s time to water. Wrinkled cacti indicate dehydration.

Q: How do I care for an orchid? A: Orchids often enter a rest period after flowering. Place them in bright, indirect light and water weekly with tepid water. Fertilise monthly from March to November. Prune the flower stalk after blooming to encourage future flowers.

Q: Finding Alternatives for Gardening Space A: If you don’t have space in your yard or it is unsuitable for gardening, consider finding a spot on a nearby lot or farm. Community gardens are often a practical solution for those seeking space to cultivate plants. These gardens can be situated on public or private land and may be located inside or outside city limits.

Q: How Community Gardens Are Organized A: Community gardens can be organized in different ways. In some cases, the landowner or public institution provides only the space, while gardeners handle soil preparation, planting, pest control, and harvesting themselves. More frequently, sponsoring institutions prepare and fertilize the soil for gardeners, and occasionally, private landowners even plant and cultivate rows of crops, leaving gardeners responsible for weeding, pest control, and harvesting.

Q: Roles and Responsibilities in Community Gardens A: Community gardens can be managed by the gardeners themselves or by private or public employees. For a community garden to be successful, it needs competent organization and supervision. Garden managers typically handle arrangements related to land use (whether public or private), soil preparation and testing, and assigning individual plots.

Q: The Role of Garden Managers A: Garden managers play a crucial role in community gardens. Their responsibilities include preparing and fertilizing the soil, laying out, marking, and assigning plots, and supervising operations and activities throughout the growing season. Effective management ensures that community gardens run smoothly and remain productive.

Q: What is really meant by the process of composting? A: Composting is a microbial process that converts plant materials such as grass clippings and leaves to a more usable organic soil amendment or mulch. Gardeners have used compost for centuries to increase soil organic matter, improve soil physical properties, and supply some of the essential nutrients for plant growth.
Q: What is compost? A: Compost is the partially decomposed remains of plants. In its final state of decomposition it is referred to as humus.

Q: Does compost have any value as a fertilizer? A: Yes, because decomposed materials have some nitrogen, phosphorous, and potassium content even though in small amounts. The addition of garden fertilizers to speed up decomposition supplies some of the nutrients as well.

Q: Can compost be used as a substitute for fertilizer in the garden? A: It can be used as a source of nutrients, however, there are not enough nutrients present in the compost to supply the needs of vegetable crops and ornamental plants. The lack of large amounts of nutrients in compost is far outweighed particle size of the material being composted depends on the final use of the compost.

Q: Is it necessary to add lime (calcium) to the compost pile? A: It is not necessary, nor is it recommended. Too much lime may cause a loss of nitrogen from the pile. Most finished compost will have a near neutral pH without the addition of lime.

Q: Is it necessary to add inoculum to the compost pile to activate the composting process? A: Inoculation with prepared microbes may hasten the process. However, there are enough microbes present on the material being composted to initiate the process.

Q: What are the best materials for composting? A: Most plant material can be used for composting. Leaves are perhaps the best material because of their availability and organic content; however, other types of organic materials such as animal manures, grass clippings, vegetable refuse, small tree limbs and shrub trimmings, coffee grounds, and rotted sawdust are considered good composting materials. Do not compost diseased plants, weeds with seeds, or invasive weeds such as morning glory and nut grass; avoid composting feces, meat products, or materials contaminated with chemicals.
Q: Is it necessary to shred materials for the compost pile? A: The finer the material is that goes into the compost pile the quicker and more thorough the decomposition.

Q: Can a rotary mower be used to shred materials? A: Yes, it works best on dry materials that are not too woody. For example, leaves can be shredded effectively by a rotary mower. It is best to use it on a hard, level surface.

Q: What is meant by Carbon to Nitrogen ratios? A: When combining any organic materials to make compost, the concept of carbon to nitrogen (C:N) ratio is critical. The micro-organisms in compost use carbon for an energy source, and nitrogen for making proteins. The proportion of these two elements used by the micro-organisms averages about 30 parts carbon to 1 part nitrogen. Given a steady diet at this 30:1 ratio they can work on organic material very quickly. The larger the number the greater the amount of carbon in proportion to nitrogen and the slower the decomposing process. Sawdust has a very high C:N ratio and decomposes fairly slowly unless some additional nitrogen is supplied. Grass clippings have a relatively low C:N ratio and decompose relatively quickly. Providing a mixture of high and low C:N materials usually results in better or faster decomposition than too much of either material.

Q: Do compost piles need turning? A: Yes, turn the pile to supply more oxygen for the microbe population and to shift undecomposed material on the edge of the pile to the center where it too will be decomposed.

Q: Do compost piles have offensive odors? A: Not if composting is done properly (i.e. provided good aeration and moisture for rapid decomposition). If animal manures are used, some odor may be detectable in the beginning but will dissipate as the process accelerates.

Q: What do you do about a neighbor who complains about composting even though it doesn’t smell? A: Set a good example by keeping your compost system as neat as possible. Remember the essentials when you compost, especially the C:N ratio because too much nitrogen can cause an odor problem. Be sure to explain the benefits of composting every chance you get. Tell them why you do it and how it works for you. They’ll catch on sooner or later.
Q: Are earwigs bad? What is their composting role? A: Earwigs are rarely a serious threat to crops and they can be an aid to the composting process as scavengers. They prefer cooler piles.

Q: How do you compost when you have too many materials that are high in nitrogen? A: Store high carbon materials (sawdust, leaves, shredded newspaper) and use them when needed. Buy peat moss and combine with the materials that are high in nitrogen.

Q: Can newspaper be composted? A: Yes, if shredded and mixed well with other materials. Newspaper is also a good mulching material and can be placed beneath wood chips for a path. The inks used today are generally non-toxic.

Q: How do you know when compost is finished? A: When it has become dark, loose and crumbly; and if in a hot pile, when it doesn’t re-heat upon turning. Sifting out unfinished materials is helpful if the aesthetics are a problem.

Q: How are food scraps stored and used to make compost? A: Store them in sealable plastic containers and layer with sawdust to minimize odor problems. They can be used by burying them under at least eight inches of soil or turned in a hot compost.
Q: Can noxious weeds and thorny plants be composted? A: Yes, but care must be taken so the compost produced does not replant the weeds where they are not wanted.

Q: How are noxious weeds such as morning glory, crabgrass, buttercup, ivy roots and blackberries composted? A: Plants that propagate vegetatively should be very thoroughly dried in the sun and then used as a compost ingredient. Or they should be composted alone and covered with black plastic to sit for as much as two years. A thorough composting in a hot system should kill most weed seeds.
Q: Can bones and meat scraps be composted? A: Yes, but there is too much potential for pest problems, so we do not recommend composting these materials.
Q: Can pet wastes be composted? A: Do not compost pet waste. Not only are they smelly, but they can be dangerous to your health.

Q: How do you balance carbon and nitrogen to make a hot pile? A: Learn C:N ratios of materials and balance mathematically. Learn C:N ratios of materials and balance intuitively. Use brown and green materials in approximately equal proportions.
Q: Can wood ashes be added to the compost pile? A: Yes, but in limited quantities.
Q: Can sod be composted? A: Yes, stacked in a pile, grass side down, kept moist and covered with black plastic. It can take up to two years to fully compost.

Q: Should the compost pile/bin be placed in the shade or sun? A: A sunny spot is best because the heat of the sun speeds decomposition. However, the pile also dries out faster and requires more frequent watering than a pile in the shade.
Q: When is a pile too small to heat up? A: For a hot compost, we recommend a minimum dimension of 3′ X 3′ X 3′. Insulation of the sides or top would help hold the heat of the process.
Q: How do you know when to turn the pile? A: If you are making hot compost, turn the pile when the internal temperature decreases below 100°F.

Q: Are slugs a problem? What is their role in composting? A: They are not a problem for the composting process – they actually contribute to the process by feeding on decaying and fresh wastes. Their proximity to the garden can, of course, be a problem.
Q: What is the easiest way to compost? A: A holding unit or bin is the easiest way to compost.
Q: Can fruit waste be composted? A: Yes. With citrus, it is best to chop the rinds as much as possible to aid decomposition. Compost them like other food wastes.
Q: Should diseased materials be used to make compost? A: As a general rule, it would be best to not compost diseased plant materials because of the chance of re-infecting your garden.

Q: When is compost ready to use? A: When the pile returns to normal temperature and the organic material crumbles easily. At this point, you should not be able to recognize the material that you put in the original pile. The composting process in the average pile takes about 6 to 8 months, though an ideally mixed and tended pile may take less than as 8 weeks to become compost.

Q: How can I use compost? A: Compost can be used to enrich the garden, to improve the soil around trees and shrubs, as a soil amendment for houseplants and when screened, as a part of seed-starting mix or lawn top dressing.

Q: Can I compost grass clippings that have been treated with pesticides? A: Some lawn herbicides may persist in the soil for 6 to 8 months. However, composting accelerates the degradation process. If treated grass clippings are composted for at least one year, pesticide residue should not be a problem when the compost is used in the garden or landscape.

Q: Will my compost smell? A: The odor of compost is a common concern, but it shouldn’t be. Good compost has an earthy aroma to it. If it has an offensive smell like ammonia or sulfur, it is not “cooking” properly. In order for compost to cook properly, you need a good mix of heat, moisture, and oxygen in your pile so that bacteria and microorganisms can do their job. Bacteria begin the composting process. Aerobic bacteria need air to live, while anaerobic bacteria can survive without it. Both aid in the decay of organic material, but the aerobic bacteria are particularly helpful because they work faster than their anaerobic cousins and do not produce an odor while working. If your compost pile begins to smell, that usually means that your aerobic friends are not getting enough oxygen. The solution? Get a pitchfork and turn your pile.

Q: Can I compost in winter? A: Yes, you can compost throughout winter. Of course, with lower temperatures, the process will significantly slow down. During mild winter days, the microorganisms in compost will continue to eat. Just like us, though, they move a little slower on really cold days.

Q: What types of things can I put in my compost pile? A: Almost anything organic will break down into compost. Grass clippings, leaves, farm animal manure, kitchen peelings, coffee grounds, and eggshells are among the usual suspects found in a compost pile. However, many people overlook other everyday items. One evening after a potluck dinner, I mentioned to a friend that I would put the leftover cabbage into my compost pile. She looked shocked and exclaimed, 'But it’s cooked!' I replied, 'Well, it may be cooked but it’s organic vegetable matter, and the bacteria and earthworms will not know the difference.' Other items to include that may not be so obvious are newspaper, sawdust, bread, cooked pasta, and weeds (before they go to seed). Wood and wood products like paper or sawdust take longer to break down, but they eventually decompose. Also, most newspapers have moved to a vegetable-based ink, so there are no concerns about composting newsprint.

Q: What types of things should I avoid putting in my compost pile? A: There are a few items that should never go into a compost pile. Diseased plants (dead or alive) shouldn’t be composted because they can spread the disease further. If you have applied chemicals like herbicides or pesticides to your lawn, those grass clippings shouldn’t be composted either. Perennial weeds, like dandelions, should be discarded as well.

Q: Does it matter in what order I add organic materials? A: Most gardeners have heard about layering their compost: a layer of dry ingredients (usually leaves), then a layer of moist ingredients (grass clippings or kitchen peelings), and so on. In an ideal world, gardeners would layer their compost because they would have the time and the energy. Truth be told, Mother Nature and her workers have composted for millennia, and they have never layered. Admittedly, though, the process is faster if your ingredients are layered.

Q: Should my compost pile be in the sun or in the shade? A: You can put your compost pile in the sun or in the shade, but putting it in the sun will hasten the composting process. Sun helps increase the temperature, so the bacteria and fungi work faster. This also means that your pile will dry out faster, especially in warm southern climates. If you do place your pile in full sun, just remember to keep it moist as it heats up.

Q: Do I have to turn the compost pile? A: I once told a neighbor who asked me this question that she had to turn her compost pile. I learned later that she decided not to compost at all that season because she didn’t have time to turn it. I’ve since clarified that statement by adding that you have to turn your pile if you want to have compost fairly quickly; turning hastens the process. But you don’t have to do it. It’s possible that, without turning, the compost will begin to smell as the anaerobic bacteria start to do their thing.

Q: Do I need to buy a compost bin? A: No. Mother Nature has never used a compost bin, and she turns out the best compost around. However, homemade bins (out of wood or wire fencing) help you build and confine your pile. The plastic tumbling compost bins are also a nice luxury, if you can afford it. They make turning effortless, the compost is easily accessible, and, better yet, they speed up the process. With a tumbling bin, you can have compost ready in a few months, whereas leaving it to Mother Nature may take an entire gardening season. The choice is yours. Either way, I’m sure you’ll find composting to be easy and rewarding. There are many good reasons to begin composting, and it’s always gratifying for me to see how much my garden flourishes.

Q: Do I need to purchase an expensive composter? A: No. Composting happens all the time in nature without our help. A $400 elevated and insulated tumbler is not necessary to create good compost. Composting does, however, require a few things: organic matter of a compostable size, periodic moisture, good drainage, and a method to keep critters out (if that is a problem for you). If all of us had unlimited space and a tractor with a front loader, we could have lovely windrows of compost. But many of us simply want an easy way to corral our pile of debris. A single wooden or mesh-wire bin or a compost pile surrounded by a wire ring both work, though they are a bit awkward to turn. If space and time allow, build three three-sided bins next to one another. Dispose of and turn debris in the first; transfer and turn decaying material in the second; and move decayed, ready-to-use compost to the third. If you have the space, place two or more three-sided slatted bins next to one another; that way, you can scoop debris back and forth from bin to bin. If you live in an apartment or condo and the only place you have for a composter is a patio or terrace, then there is obviously a need for a covered bin. But here’s the catch: Small composters such as rolling bins, tumblers, and stationary bins fill quickly and have to be turned frequently. Of course, the biggest advantage to an enclosed compost pile is that it excludes unwanted wildlife. But if your intention is simply to reduce degradable waste, who cares if a possum carries off some potato peels? If varmints are a concern, be sure your compost pile is enclosed.

Q: Is a compost starter necessary? A: You do not need to spend $10 to $20 to get your pile started. There are plenty of microbes available for free. In fact, there are microbes in just about everything we throw on our compost pile—think of all those uneaten tomatoes disintegrating on the kitchen counter. If you are starting a brand-new pile, a shovelful of leaf mold or other naturally composted matter from the woods is a great source of the bacteria and fungi needed to get things going. In an older pile, the compost and soil are chock-full of all the fungi and bacteria you need to break down organic matter; scoop from the bottom and sprinkle on top as you turn.

Q: What’s all the fuss about carbon and nitrogen? A: Aerobic bacteria, the workhorses of decomposition, need carbon and nitrogen to do their job. Experts recommend a carbon-to-nitrogen ratio of 25:1 to 30:1 for the fastest breakdown of materials; however, the numbers just need to be in the ballpark. The general rule is to have enough greens for your browns. Typically, green, fresh, and colorful debris provides a good source of nitrogen. Coffee grounds are an exception; they are full of nitrogen. Other browns and beiges—chopped-up autumn leaves and twigs, wood chips, and straw—provide carbon. Although a pile of autumn leaves will eventually break down on its own, adding some high-nitrogen lawn clippings, vegetable scraps, and coffee grounds will speed things along. If your pile is just sitting there as recognizable chunks, you may need more nitrogen-heavy additions. If it’s working up a big stink, back off on the nitrogen and add more carbon-rich items, such as leaves and straw. If you’re adding both kitchen waste, which is typically high in nitrogen, and yard waste, which is generally high in carbon, then your pile should be in good shape as long as you mix the waste before or after adding it to the pile. And contrary to some beliefs, there is no need to add lime to compost. Many microbes are most active at a moderately low pH.

Q: What Is Composting? A: Composting entails the collection and storage of your plant-based trash in a way that’ll turn it into soil. It’s really just letting nature do its thing, with microbes breaking down the waste’s organic material.

Q: Where Should You Make It? A: Find a secluded spot in your backyard to set up your compost site. You have a lot of options for how to collect it: drums that turn, barrels with an opening near the bottom, wooden bins, or simply a hole in the ground.

Q: What Can You Put in Your Compost? A: Try to go for one part 'green' waste (nitrogen-based, wet content) to three parts 'brown' waste (carbon-based, dry content). Green waste includes your veggie and fruit scraps from the kitchen, recently pulled weeds, grass clippings, green leaves, and other foliage that hasn’t died yet. Your browns, however, can include dead plants, as well as paper products like tissues (even cotton swabs!), dryer lint, spent potting soil, and dry leaves. The ratio of wet to dry items does matter, but it isn’t rigid. Whatever you throw in your compost, don’t include dairy products, meats, eggs, or fats and oils. These will make it smelly, attracting animals and unwanted bugs.
Q: Do You Need to Mix Your Compost? A: Mixing compost does really speed up the process, but is by no means necessary.

Q: How Do You Know When It’s Done? A: Your compost has become actual compost once it looks like black soil. It’ll smell earthy, but not foul. Most traditional compost piles will be ready in three months depending on how much you have and how much it gets moved around.

Q: How Do You Stop Animals from Getting into It? A: Sharing with the animals isn’t necessarily a bad thing, but it could get sloppy. If you don’t like the mess, an open bin isn’t for you. Go for the composters with tight-fitting lids.
